intro: Chiliadenus antiatlanticus, commonly known as the Atlantic chiliadenus, is a rare and endemic plant species native to the coastal regions of North Africa. It is characterized by its succulent, fleshy leaves that store water, adapting to the arid and saline conditions of its habitat. The plant produces small, yellowish-green flowers that bloom during the rainy season, typically in late spring or early summer. Its root system is deep and extensive, allowing it to access groundwater in nutrient-poor soils. Due to habitat loss and climate change, Chiliadenus antiatlanticus is considered vulnerable and is of interest to botanists studying plant adaptation to extreme environments.
